awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: IA: Collaborative Research: From Bytes to Watts - A Data Science Solution to Improve Wind Energy Reliability and Operation
awd_abstract_narration:
The collective efforts in aerospace, civil, electrical, and mechanical engineering areas have led to remarkable progresses in wind energy. Larger turbines are designed and installed, and wind farms are nowadays built at locations where wind is even more intermittent and maintenance equipment is less accessible. This adds new challenges to ensuring operational reliability. To cope with these challenges, along with the rapid advancement in microelectronics, modern wind farms are equipped with a large number and variety of sensors, including, at the turbine level, anemometers, tachometers, accelerometers, thermometers, strain sensors, and power meters, and at the farm level, anemometers, vanes, sonars, thermometers, humidity meters, pressure meters, among others. It is worth noting that all these data are currently analyzed/utilized only in their respective domains. The big data challenges in this project include how to best use spatio-temporal data for wind forecast, how to use data of different nature (wind, power, load etc.) and data of different sources (physical data versus computer simulation data) for power production assessment in a computationally efficient manner, and finally how to integrate these three sets of solutions into a reliable and efficient computational platform. The proposed research and education activities will make a paradigm shift in the wind industry by demonstrating how dramatically data science innovations can benefit the industry. The PIs will disseminate the research findings through classroom teaching, journal/conference publications, industry workshops, and data/software sharing. The summer internship opportunities and undergraduate research help train the next generation workforce to be better versed with data science methodologies.

The critical barrier to cost effective wind power and its general adoption is partly rooted in wind stochasticity, severely complicating wind power production optimization and cost reduction. The long-term viability of wind energy hinges upon a good understanding of its production reliability, which is affected in turn by the predictability of wind and power productivity of wind turbines. Furthermore, the productivity of a wind turbine comprises two aspects: its ability of converting wind into power during its operation and the availability of wind turbines. Three inter-related research efforts will enhance wind energy reliability and productivity): (1) spatio-temporal analysis (for wind forecast) (2) conditional density estimation (for wind-to-power conversion assessment); and (3) importance sampling (for turbine reliability assessment and improvement). Significant data resourced provided by industry partners in the research, coupled with models and computational resources, will enable better prediction of wind profiles and utilization.  In addition, the team will develop dedicated reconfigurable field programmable gate array (FPGA) processors that will be 50 to 500 times faster than general-purpose CPUs for both on-site and central control processing and have small form-factor, low cost and energy efficient to enable agile development under severe outdoor conditions at wind farms.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
This NSF project aims at incorporating data science methods to improve the predictability of wind and the productivity of wind turbines. Our team worked to address the technical challenges through providing solutions to how to best use spatio-temporal data for wind forecasting, and how to use data of different natures and data of different sources for power production assessment in a computationally efficient manner. Several technical research problems have been investigated. The team quantified the dynamics of the local wind field and develop appropriate spatio-temporal models for enhancing wind speed or wind power prediction in multi-turbine wind farms. Data-driven power curve models have been devised, which quantify the wind turbine productivity under stochastic, non-stationary wind and other environmental inputs. Further, the team developed a new approach to calibrate engineering wake models under big data settings by casting the problem into a stochastic optimization framework. The spatio-temporal analysis within a wind farm has been extended to assess wind resource over geographically dispersed areas. Finally, the team devised variance reduction methods for assessing wind turbine reliability using aeroelastic stochastic simulations. Noting that multiple atmospheric conditions impose substantial stress on the turbine structure, the team investigated how multiple environmental factors, as well as their interactions, collectively affect the turbine reliability. Specifically, the team devised a new nonparametric importance sampling method that can quantify the contributions of each environmental factor and its interactions with other factors, while avoiding computational problems and data sparsity issue arising in rare event simulation.

With the resulting research outcomes, 14 research papers, including nine journal papers and five conference papers, have been published in peer-reviewed journals and proceedings. Further, four additional new papers are under review in peer-reviewed journals. Among them, two papers were selected as Best Student Paper Finalists, one in the INFORMS QSR section and the other in the IISE Data Analytics & Information Systems subdivision. Two participating students completed their dissertations. The research findings have been presented in various conferences, including INFORMS, ISERC, and IEEE Conference on Automation Science and Engineering.

The majority of wind energy research thus far focuses on improving the design and control of turbines and grid connections, primarily carried out by domain-specific experts in aerospace, civil, electrical, and mechanical engineering. Although these domain-specific improvements involve various sensor data, the heterogeneous data that are continually being accumulated have not been analyzed in a systematic manner, mainly because of the disconnection between domain experts and data scientists. This project can make a paradigm shift in the wind industry by demonstrating how dramatically data science innovations can benefit the industry. Moreover, this project contributed toward the preparation of a future workforce in the field of energy and sustainability through an array of mechanisms including the integration of under-represented students in the STEM field into wind energy research and opportunities for students to interact with researchers in different fields and domain experts.

 


Last Modified: 12/09/2022
Modified by: Eunshin Byon

Our team worked to address the technical challenges through providing solutions to how to best use spatio-temporal data for wind forecasting, and how to use data of different natures and data of different sources for power production assessment in a computationally efficient manner. Several technical research problems have been investigated. Data-driven power curve models have been devised, which quantify the wind turbine productivity under stochastic, non-stationary wind and other environmental inputs. The spatio-temporal analysis within a wind farm has been extended to assess wind resource over geographically dispersed areas. Specifically, the team devised a new nonparametric importance sampling method that can quantify the contributions of each environmental factor and its interactions with other factors, while avoiding computational problems and data sparsity issue arising in rare event simulation.
With the resulting research outcomes, 14 research papers, including nine journal papers and five conference papers, have been published in peer-reviewed journals and proceedings. Among them, two papers were selected as Best Student Paper Finalists, one in the INFORMS QSR section and the other in the IISE Data Analytics & Information Systems subdivision. The majority of wind energy research thus far focuses on improving the design and control of turbines and grid connections, primarily carried out by domain-specific experts in aerospace, civil, electrical, and mechanical engineering. Moreover, this project contributed toward the preparation of a future workforce in the field of energy and sustainability through an array of mechanisms including the integration of under-represented students in the STEM field into wind energy research and opportunities for students to interact with researchers in different fields and domain experts.
